Authors: Monostori L., Ilie-Zudor E., Kádár B., Karnok D., Pfeiffer A., Kemény Zs., Szathmári M.
Title: Novel it solutions for increasing transparency in production and in supply chains
Abstract: The paper summarises the main challenges and problems related to transparency in production firms and networks. The transparency problem of production are treated from three aspects, i.e., factory level data gathering tight-coupled with productions simulation; extracting knowledge from large, complex, time-dependent noisy and anomalous process logs; and identity-based tracking and tracing services within and beyond organizational borders. For all these fields of industrial relevance novel approaches and solutions are presented.
Author Keywords: Auto identification; Data mining; Information and communication technologies; Production; Transparency
Index Keywords: Complex networks; Production; Supply chains; Transparency; Auto identifications; Data gathering; Identity-based; Information and Communication Technologies; IT solution; Time dependent; Tracking and tracing; Data mining

Authors: Danne C., Dangelmaier W., Häusler P.
Title: Complexity-induced production and inventory cost in consumer goods supply chains
Abstract: In virtually every branch of manufacturing industries, ever growing assortment variety leads to an increasing complexity of production and distribution systems. For consumer-driven industries like the fast-moving consumer goods (FMCG) industry, the cost effects of this growing complexity have to be considered in all strategic decisions regarding assortment size and structure. As stated in earlier works of the authors, the important practical question to be answered is what effects on the configuration of the production and distribution network and related costs can be expected if the assortment is changed in a particular way?. This paper presents the results of the development and application of the decision support system (DSS) Complana. This system was applied to the cloths' supply chain of an international household product manufacturer to evaluate the most relevant assortment dependent cost positions for a production and distribution network, focusing on the areas of inventory management and production execution.
Author Keywords: Assortment complexity; Inventory management; Production planning; Supply chain modelling
Index Keywords: Artificial intelligence; Chains; Complex networks; Costs; Decision support systems; Inventory control; Manufacture; Production control; Supply chains; Assortment complexity; Decision support system (dss); Development and applications; Fast moving consumer goods; Inventory management; Production and distribution networks; Production Planning; Supply chain modelling; Supply chain management

Authors: Tavares J.J.P.Z.S., Fonseca J.P.S.
Title: Supply chain didactic testing bench with automated planning tool
Abstract: In the last 50 years Supply Chain Management (SCM) became a business lever. There were developed many tools related with Supply Chain Management. On the other hand, Artificial Intelligence also was increased, with expert systems, neural networks, genetic algorithms, fuzzy logic and especially, automated planners. SCM and automated planning are closed; however, their integration is still an open issue. In this case, the didactic bench simulates transport systems, widely used in manufacturing process and logistics. It is integrated with itSimple, a knowledge engineering tool used for modeling planning domains and it is controlled by a Programmable Logic Controller (PLC). Example is presented to investigate how automated planners solutions can be applied in SCM.
Author Keywords: Automated planning; ItSimple; Supply Chain Management
Index Keywords: Artificial intelligence; Automation; Chains; Expert systems; Fuzzy logic; Fuzzy neural networks; Genetic algorithms; Planning; Automated planning; ItSimple; Manufacturing process; Planning domains; Programmable logic controllers (PLC); Supply chain managements (SCM); Testing bench; Transport systems; Supply chain management

Authors: Döring A., Dangemaier W., Laroque C.
Title: Potentials of automated event handling in supply chains using intelligent control methods
Abstract: Modern value-added processes will be globally cross-linked through outsourcing and reduction of real net output ratio. Therefore logistical planning and control processes become more complex. Events in supply networks and their consequences to the partners in the supply network will be hard to overlook without using computer based decision support system. This paper describes such a decision support system that learns rules for controlling a production network. In detail the system architecture will be described, requirements to such a system will be identified and a solution developed at the Heinz Nixdorf Institute in Paderborn will be presented. The solution is based on a Q-learning approach supported by a k-means clustering algorithm.
Author Keywords: Change planning; Event handling; Q-Learning; Supply chain management
Index Keywords: Artificial intelligence; Chains; Clustering algorithms; Complex networks; Decision support systems; Supply chain management; Event handling; K-Means clustering algorithm; Logistical planning; Production network; Q-learning; Q-learning approach; System architectures; Value-added process; Process control

Authors: Zouzelkova I.
Title: OLAP solution for supply chain risk management
Abstract: OLAP is a multidimensional technology offering a complex view on aggregated data. Qualities of this technology can be successfully used in Supply Chain Risk Management (SCRM). OLAP seems to be suitable for this kind of application because it shows data according to time, a process and a level of company hierarchy. These data can support strategic decision-making of storage managers as well as company top management. The primary focus of this paper is on advantages and disadvantages of OLAP used in SCRM. It discusses different risk factors, mentions integration of OLAP in Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) software and deals with interconnection between different data sources and OLAP.
Author Keywords: Data mining; OLAP; Risk factors; Supply chain risk management
Index Keywords: Data mining; Digital storage; Enterprise resource planning; Industry; Manufacture; Risk management; Supply chains; Aggregated datum; Different risk factors; Enterprise resource planning (ERP); OLAP; Risk factors; Strategic decision making; Supply chain risk management; Supply chain risk management (SCRM); Information management

Authors: Hegmanns T., Toth M.
Title: Rfid-based real-time decision support in supply chains
Abstract: For an effective global order management, the concepts of RFID and company-wide information brokerage offer promising technological background. This paper will introduce the research project RAN (RFID-based Automotive Network) which develops a new way of collecting and sharing RFID based information in supply networks. This paves the way for new IT-systems, so called Logistic Assistant Systems (LAS), which use this new real-time process information for improving decision support. This article describes a simulation-based decision-support system based on real-time RFID event information from the supply chain. Copyright © (2011) by CAL-TEK S.r.l.
Author Keywords: Capable-to-promise planning; Rfid; Simulation-based decision support systems; Supply chain management; Supply chain simulation
Index Keywords: Artificial intelligence; Radio frequency identification (RFID); Supply chain management; Automotive networks; Capable to promise; Decision supports; Global ordering; Information brokerage; Real-time decisions; Real-time process; Supply chain simulation; Decision support systems

Authors: De Cindio B., Longo F., Mirabelli G., Pizzuti T.
Title: Modelling a traceability system for a food supply chain: Standards, technologies and software tools
Abstract: The aim of this article is to define the state of the art of the international regulatory framework for the food industry, standards, technologies and software utilized for modelling the food supply chain, analyzing for them the advantages and the disadvantages. Traceability systems can help to know food origin and monitor means of transport and distribution, create "hallmarks" and improve commercial potential (external o supply chain traceability). On the other hand, for a single company, there are many advantages in adopting a traceability system such as avoiding food adulteration, improving control systems, guaranteeing high levels of quality, increasing health and safety using transparency during the entire process chain. Copyright © (2011) by CAL-TEK S.r.l.
Author Keywords: Decision support system; Food supply chain; Tracing; Tracking
Index Keywords: Artificial intelligence; Decision support systems; Food supply; Surface discharges; Commercial potential; Food adulterations; Food industries; Health and safety; International regulatory framework; State of the art; Traceability systems; Tracing; Supply chains

Authors: Bockholt F., Raabe W., Toth M.
Title: Logistic assistance systems for collaborative supply chain planning
Abstract: Global market changes and new business strategies have changed logistic processes. Today, complex supply chains contain numerous manufacturing levels with long-distance transport. Effective planning and control have to follow various objectives like cost reduction, reliability and flexibility, but also ecological targets. This paper introduces Logistic Assistance Systems (LAS) for planning and decision support in supply chains. Designed as lean software systems, LAS focus on logistic planning processes and integrate selected methods for data management, information processing and supply chain planning. First achievements with LAS at Volkswagen Group are now followed by a new promising project. Copyright © 2011 Inderscience Enterprises Ltd.
Author Keywords: Decision-support system; LAS; Logistic assistance system; Supply chain collaboration; Supply chain planning
Index Keywords: Artificial intelligence; Cost reduction; Decision support systems; International trade; Lanthanum; Supply chains; Assistance system; Collaborative supply chains; Complex supply chain; Ecological targets; Effective planning; Long-distance transport; Supply chain collaboration; Supply chain planning; Information management

Authors: Di J.
Title: Notice of Retraction: Research on pulled ATO supply chain coordination with allowance-penalty contract
Abstract: This paper considers a muti-supplier, single assembler ATO(assemble to order) supply chain with price-dependent demand, where the leading assembler assembles one final product. We builds three decisionmaking models including centralized model, wholesale price contract and allowance-penalty contract, then seeks the optimal capacity of each supplier and optimal retail price of the assembler in each model. Based on analysis of comparison, it's found that single wholesale price contract can't coordinate the whole supply chain; however, through proper-designed contract parameters, allowancepenalty contract may realize supply chain coordination perfectly. © 2011 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Allowance-penalty contract; Assemble to order; Component; Supply chain coordination
Index Keywords: Artificial intelligence; Assemble to order; Centralized models; Component; Decision making models; Optimal retail price; Price dependent demand; Supply chain coordination; Wholesale price contract; Supply chains

Authors: Zhao J.-F.
Title: Notice of Retraction: A new kind of supply chain management inventory optimization model based on cooperation and coordination mechanisms
Abstract: Cooperation and coordination problem is one of the main problems of supply chain inventory optimization controlling currently. The MTP (matter, thing and people) ideology was introduced and used to optimize the traditional F.Harris inventory model. On this basis, a new kind of supply chain management inventory optimization batch Elasticity model based on cooperation and coordination mechanisms was established. Optimizing results were analyzed through batch flexibility theory based on coordination mechanisms. A new and feasible method to optimize inventory management was provided. In this thesis, the inventory optimization problems were discussed from the quantitative study perspective and based on cooperation and coordination mechanisms using MTP ideology and combining with F.Harris inventory model. © 2011 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Batch elasticity model; F. Harris inventory model; SCM
Index Keywords: Artificial intelligence; Elasticity; Inventory control; Optimization; Cooperation and coordination; Coordination mechanisms; Elasticity model; Inventory management; Inventory modeling; Inventory optimization; Quantitative study; Supply chain inventories; Supply chain management

Authors: Kumar V., Mishra N., Chan F.T.S., Verma A.
Title: Managing warehousing in an agile supply chain environment: An F-AIS algorithm based approach
Abstract: In recent years, application of the agile concept in the manufacturing sector has been researched extensively to reduce the varying effect of customer demands. However, most of the research work is focused on the shop floor of different manufacturing processes, while issues concerning the control of warehouse scheduling in a supply chain have been neglected so far. Realising this in the present research an attempt has been made to address the scheduling aspect of a warehouse in an agile supply chain environment. To resolve the warehouse problem in this paper, the authors have proposed a new Fuzzy incorporated Artificial Immune System Algorithm (F-AIS). This algorithm encapsulates the salient features of a fuzzy logic controller and immune system. The proposed algorithm has been compared with genetic algorithm (GA), simulated annealing (SA) and artificial immune system (AIS) algorithm to reveal the efficacy of the proposed F-AIS algorithm. © 2011 Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: agile; AIS; fuzzy; scheduling; supply chain; warehousing
Index Keywords: Artificial intelligence; Fuzzy logic; Genetic algorithms; Immune system; Industrial research; Manufacture; Scheduling; Simulated annealing; Supply chains; Warehouses; agile; Artificial immune system algorithms; fuzzy; Fuzzy logic controllers; Manufacturing process; Manufacturing sector; Warehouse scheduling; warehousing; Agile manufacturing systems

Authors: Leukel J., Jacob A., Karaenke P., Kirn S., Klein A.
Title: Individualization of goods and services: Towards a logistics knowledge infrastructure for agile supply chains
Abstract: Our research is directed towards agile supply chains enabling enterprises to quickly respond to individual customer demand. From this perspective, agility encompasses three dimensions of adaptivity: space, time, and economy. Supply chain agility can be achieved by exploiting the most fundamental resource of any enterprise: knowledge. Studying supply chains, we regard all their tiers, participants, and potential relationships, as the search space for fulfilling individual customer demand. We study supply chains from a knowledge-based coordination perspective and regard logistics as the guiding conceptualization. The contribution of this research is a logistics knowledge infrastructure. We report about applying parts of this infrastructure to coordination problems in three selected case studies. Copyright © 2011, Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Artificial intelligence; Knowledge based systems; Agile supply chains; Case-studies; Coordination problems; Individual customers; Knowledge based; Search spaces; Supply chain agility; Three dimensions; Supply chains

Authors: Olson E.C., Haapala K.R., Okudan G.E.
Title: Integration of sustainability issues during early design stages in a global supply chain context
Abstract: A method is introduced to incorporate sustainability considerations in the early design stages, while simultaneously accounting for supply chain factors, such as cost and lead time. Overall, this work is our first step in understanding the trade-offs between sustainability metrics and more traditional supply chain performance metrics (i.e., cost and lead time). Based on our understanding of these trade-offs, we intend to help build computational artificial intelligence tools that can exploit these trade-offs for improved customization in products. Copyright © 2011, Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Artificial intelligence; Commerce; Economic and social effects; Supply chains; Sustainable development; Artificial intelligence tools; Early design stages; Global supply chain; Supply chain performance; Sustainability considerations; Sustainability issues; Sustainability metrics; Trade off; Costs

Authors: Miao Z., Xu K.
Title: Modeling and simulation of lean supply chain with the consideration of delivery consolidation
Abstract: An integrated production-inventory-delivery lean supply chain model is discussed. The model is integrated with production, supply and distribution through cost. And the delivery of purchasing and distribution is consolidated. A non-linear programming model with multivariable is proposed. The length of path and the frequency of delivery are regarded as decision-making variables. The optimal delivery path and the length of path are first solved by using improved ant colony optimization algorithm. And the optimal frequency of delivery and the batch of delivery are achieved. Last, the model is validated through an example and the result indicates the model is simple and practical. Moreover it is meaningful for practice.
Author Keywords: Delivery consolidation; Improved ant colony optimization algorithm; Lean supply chain modeling; Optimal delivery batch; Optimal delivery path
Index Keywords: Artificial intelligence; Decision making; Nonlinear programming; Supply chains; Delivery path; Improved ant colony optimization; Integrated production; Lean supply chains; Model and simulation; Multi variables; Optimal delivery batch; Optimal frequency; Ant colony optimization

Authors: Ferreira L., Borenstein D.
Title: Normative agent-based simulation for supply chain planning
Abstract: This paper presents an agent-based simulation framework for supply chain (SC) planning, introducing the notion of normative agent. The analysis of the relevant literature shows that most research works carried out in this area aim to handle specific problems and contexts. Although some methodologies and more generic solutions have been proposed, they are not able to cope with SCs in which regulation plays an important role, whether issued by a government agent or by an international institution. Several SCs, such as in the energy, food, chemical, and forestry areas, are highly regulated. Explicitly modelling the actors involved in the regulation of SCs using normative agents allowed us to evaluate the potential benefits of alternative strategies for planning of regulated SCs. The modelling of a biodiesel SC is presented as a case study. © 2011 Operational Research Society Ltd. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: agent-based modelling; artificial intelligence; planning; simulation; supply chain
Index Keywords: Artificial intelligence; Autonomous agents; Computational methods; Planning; Agent based simulation; Agent-based modelling; Generic solutions; Normative agents; Potential benefits; simulation; Specific problems; Supply chain planning; Supply chains

Authors: Flatt R., Kirchberg M., Link S.
Title: The quadrupel - A model for automating intermediary selection in supply chain management
Abstract: The selection of intermediaries is a fundamental and challenging problem in supply chain management. We propose a conceptual process model to guide the supply chain coordinator through the selection process. Besides the support of our model for the agility, adaptability and alignment of the target supply chain, it also provides extensive automated assistance for the selection of tactics by off-the-shelf tools from the area of artificial intelligence. © 2011 The authors and IOS Press. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Artificial Intelligence; Decision Support; Intermediary Selection; Strategic Concept Development; Supply Chain Modeling
Index Keywords: Artificial intelligence; Decision support systems; Automated assistance; Decision supports; Intermediary Selection; Process Modeling; Strategic concepts; Supply chain modeling; Supply chain management

Authors: Yu B., Zhang Y.
Title: A method for evaluation of green degree in green supply chain
Abstract: Green supply chain management is a method to reduce the ecological impact of the whole supply chain and make the most efficient use of resources. In this paper, the data mining (DM) technique is utilised to evaluate green degree in green supply chain. Then the process of the evaluation is given and a classification model of multivariate decision tree based on rough set is proposed. Finally, a simulation analysis is given to show the application of this method.
Author Keywords: Data mining; Green degree; Green supply chain; Sustainable development
Index Keywords: Decision trees; Supply chain management; Sustainable development; Classification models; Ecological impacts; Green degree; Green supply chain; Green supply chain management; Multivariate decision tree; Simulation analysis; Data mining

Authors: Zou Z., Tseng T.-L., Sohn H., Song G., Gutierrez R.
Title: A rough set based approach to distributor selection in supply chain management
Abstract: Distributor's selection is an important issue in Supply chain management, particularly in the current competitive environment. The current research works provide only conceptual, descriptive, and simulation results, focusing mainly on firm resources and general marketing factors. The selection and evaluation of distributors generally incorporate qualitative information; however, analyzing qualitative information is difficult by standard statistical techniques. Consequently, a more suitable approach is desired. In this paper, a method based on Rough set theory, which has been recognized as a powerful tool in dealing with qualitative data in the literature, is introduced and modified for preferred distributor selection. We derived certain decision rules which are able to facilitate distributor selection and identified several significant features based on an empirical study conducted in China. © 2010 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Data mining; Distributor selections; Rough set theory (RST); Supply chain management (SCM)
Index Keywords: Competitive environment; Current researches; Decision rules; Distributor selections; Empirical studies; Marketing factors; Qualitative data; Qualitative information; Rough set; Rough-set based; Simulation result; Standard statistical techniques; Supply chain management (SCM); Data mining; Feature extraction; Quality assurance; Reliability analysis; Robot learning; Supply chain management; Supply chains; Rough set theory

Authors: Chang J.-Q., Cheng G., Luo C.-L., Ma X.-F.
Title: Evaluation of supply chain partnership based on rough set theory
Abstract: After the Era of Economic Crisis, if an enterprise wants to win the advantageous opportunity, it must have reliable supply chain partners. So the research of evaluation on supply chain partners has become hot contents of supply chain management. Based on the history data of some typical enterprises in choosing partners, this paper use rough sets theory to reduce evaluation indexes. Thus we can obtain a more refined index system without influencing decision-making effect. A series of evaluation rules is also be launched as foundation for the enterprise to build intelligentized partner selection decision support system. It can improve the decision-making efficiency and reduce costs. This method has certain practical significance. © 2010 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Indicator; Partnership; Rough set; Supply chain
Index Keywords: Economic crisis; Evaluation index; Evaluation rules; History data; Index systems; Indicator; Partner selection; Partnership; Rough set; Rough Sets Theory; Supply chain partners; Artificial intelligence; Decision making; Decision support systems; Decision theory; Industrial engineering; Industry; Rough set theory; Supply chains; Supply chain management

Authors: Wan Y., Bai Y.
Title: Research about openness cycle of supply chain network
Abstract: This paper addresses that follower strategy of supply chain management to make its SCM open, make five and collaborate with strategic gartner and gradually build up Supply Chain Network is considered; the key factor to gain the enterprise competitiveness. The SCN, including partners offour aspects: product moving channel, capital supply channel, S&T transfer channel, and R&D cooperation channel, is more open, interactive. ©2010 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Enterprise core competitiveness; Semiconductor Manufacturfing International Corporation(SMIC); Supply Chain Management(SCM)
Index Keywords: Core competitiveness; Gartner; International corporation; Key factors; Supply Chain Management(SCM); Supply chain network; Supply channels; Transfer channel; Artificial intelligence; Competition; Industry; Research and development management; Supply chains; Supply chain management

Authors: Wang F., Wang S.
Title: Risk early waming of supply chain based on D-S evidence theory
Abstract: Competition of the supply chain has been considered to be the main trend of business. However, the cooperation of supply chain between relevant organizations, because of information asymmetry, information distortion, market, political, economic, legal and other factors uncertainty, led to the existence of various risks. At the same time as the unique nature of the supply chain, damage resulting from risk of the supply chain is much more serious than on the individual enterprise. A small risk may causes supply chain radical chain reaction, causing destruction of the supply chain of the upstream and downstream enterprise as well as the entire supply chain damage and loss. In this paper, evidence theory is used to identify the belieffunction within the framework of the subset, belieffunction according to the maximum to determine the results of the comprehensive evaluation of the project, and an example to illustrate the practicality and effectiveness. ©2010 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Early warning; Evidence theory; Risk
Index Keywords: Comprehensive evaluation; D S evidence theory; Early warning; Evidence theories; Information asymmetry; Information distortion; Radical chain reactions; Artificial intelligence; Supply chain management; Supply chains

Authors: Marcellino F.J.M., Sichman J.S.
Title: A holonic multi-agent model for oil industry supply chain management
Abstract: Very few industries can benefit more from maximizing supply chain efficiencies than the oil and gas companies [1]. However, the behavior of such systems is too complex to be treated analytically. On the other hand, multi-agent systems show great similarity with respect to supply chains, and provide the flexibility to model the complexities and dynamics of real world chains without excessive simplifying assumptions. Since supply chain management deals with a recursive structure, it becomes appropriate to employ holonic agents for its modeling. Thus, this work aims at developing a holonic multi-agent model for a typical oil industry supply chain. A simple case study is analyzed as a proof-of-concept of the proposed approach. The obtained results motivate us to continue extending the model in order to make it more realistic. © 2010 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Holonic Agents; Multi-Agent Systems; Oil Industry Supply Chains
Index Keywords: Holonic Agents; Holonics; Multi-Agent Model; Oil and gas companies; Oil industries; Proof of concept; Recursive structure; Simplifying assumptions; Supply chain efficiency; Holonics; Multi-Agent Model; Oil and gas companies; Oil industries; Proof of concept; Recursive structure; Simplifying assumptions; Supply chain efficiency; Gas industry; Multi agent systems; Public utilities; Supply chain management; Artificial intelligence; Gas industry; Intelligent agents; Public utilities; Supply chain management; Supply chains; Multi agent systems

Authors: Tsadikovich D., Levner E., Tell H.
Title: AI-based integrated scheduling of production and transportation operations within military supply chains
Abstract: Maintaining the military weapon systems requires that spare parts of military equipment are available where and when they are needed. We focus on integrated demand-responsive scheduling of operations within two-echelon military supply chains consisting of production and transportation operations. Integration across these operations is achieved by introducing an additional intermediary module into the mathematical model which is solved by a new two-level artificial-intelligence (AI)-based algorithm. In order to carry out this task we introduce and analyze two performance measures: time of response and military effectiveness. A new solution method based on integer programming techniques in combination with AI-based heuristic search is derived. The discrete-event simulation tool - ARENA 11.0, is used to implement the integrated scheduling method. © 2010 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: AI-based heuristic search; military supply chain; Planning and scheduling; simulation; supply chain management
Index Keywords: Heuristic search; Integrated scheduling; Military supply chains; Military weapon systems; New solutions; Performance measure; Planning and scheduling; Programming technique; simulation; Spare parts; Transportation operations; Heuristic search; Integrated scheduling; Military supply chains; Military weapon systems; Performance measure; Planning and scheduling; Production and transportations; Simulation; Artificial intelligence; Heuristic methods; Integer programming; Logistics; Mathematical models; Military equipment; Modular robots; Planning; Supply chains; Artificial intelligence; Discrete event simulation; Heuristic algorithms; Heuristic methods; Integer programming; Military equipment; Modular robots; Supply chain management; Transportation; Supply chain management; Scheduling

Authors: Laínez J.M., Reklaitis G.V., Puigjaner L.
Title: Linking marketing and supply chain models for improved business strategic decision support
Abstract: A supply chain (SC) model incorporating business strategic decision components is an important tool for gaining a competitive edge in todays global market. Enterprise models of this type must encompass not only the SC, but also the demand chain since understanding the market is crucial for developing good business policies. To operate effectively, marketing activities must be coordinated with other corporate functional areas. Specifically, managers should evaluate the trade-off between marketing and SC decisions to enhance the performance of the overall metric: the shareholders value. Recently, there has been significant progress in developing marketing science models for reaching quantitatively based marketing decisions. In this work, we build on these developments to formulate a mathematical model that accounts for the main relevant business functionalities. The result is a MINLP formulation which optimizes the SC and marketing strategic decisions in an integrated fashion. Moreover, a financial model that evaluates the enterprise value is also incorporated. © 2010 Elsevier Ltd.
Author Keywords: Business decision support systems; Enterprise wide optimization; Marketing models
Index Keywords: Business decisions; Business policies; Competitive edges; Demand chains; Enterprise models; Enterprise values; Enterprise-wide optimization; Financial models; Functional areas; Global market; Integrated fashion; Marketing activities; Marketing decision; Marketing models; Strategic decisions; Supply chain models; Artificial intelligence; Decision making; Decision support systems; Decision theory; Industry; International trade; Mathematical models; Optimization; Supply chain management; Supply chains; Marketing

Authors: Chen W.
Title: Value management of supply chain and data mining system
Abstract: To establish the value management system of supply chain is to integrate the subsystems of the value chain through the effective value-management method and the guidance of the system of the supply chain value strategy, is to maximize the supply chain value, is to establish the right decision-making matrix of supply chain value and choose the appropriate value strategy of supply chain. The scientific and practical data mining system of supply chain is an important basis of the value system of supply chain to achieve the best efficiency. Through the information transmission in data mining system of supply chain, the value management system and the process management system of supply chain can achieve an organic integration, which to realize the best efficiency of the whole operations of supply chain system. © 2010 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Data mining; Supply chain; Value managemen
Index Keywords: Chain value; Data mining system; Information transmission; matrix; Process management systems; Supply chain systems; Value chains; Value managemen; Value management; Value strategies; Value systems; Chains; Data mining; Decision making; Electronic commerce; Government data processing; Mining machinery; Supply chains; Supply chain management

Authors: Nag B.
Title: Intelligent systems in operations: Methods, models and applications in the supply chain
Abstract: Artificial Intelligence and other Intelligent Systems heavily contribute to evolution and growth in the field of Operations Management. Intelligent Systems in Operations: Models, Methods, and Applications introduces current and original research in intelligent systems and methodologies. This book intends to provide knowledge and insights on present and future AI applications in OM from current research-oriented thinking on AI-based systems in the benefit of OM tools and decisions in terms of theoretical and empirical models, methods and their comparisons, and actual and proposed applications. A must have for industry professionals seeking examples of AI applications in OM, researchers looking for material that can be extended into further research, and graduate students in the field. © 2010 by IGI Global. All rights reserved.

Authors: Pimentel B.S., Mateus G.R., Almeida F.A.
Title: Mathematical models for optimizing the global mining supply chain
Abstract: The present chapter discusses the application of intelligent decision-support systems - mathematical programming-based in particular - to operations management within the mining industry. The underlying production and distribution planning and scheduling problems have often been addressed individually, in disregard of upstream and downstream operations. A supply chain approach to mining operations, however, requires an integrated perspective which takes into account mine, railway and port operations, as well as domestic and international supply stations served by appropriate logistics channels. Three main topics are discussed here: recent operations research developments in the mining industry; integrated approaches towards the development of decision-support systems to address a global mining supply chain; and possible solution approaches to the integrated problems. The main thread is oriented to mathematical programming approaches, but relevant applications of simulation and artificial intelligence techniques are also discussed. © 2010, IGI Global.

Authors: Hiremath N.C., Sahu S., Tiwari M.K.
Title: Optimization for efficient supply chain using swarm intelligence: An outsourcing perspective
Abstract: The thrust of global economy drives the organizations to outsource process, parts, and labor, virtually anywhere in the world and get the desired combination of low cost and high quality. However, ineffective utilization of shipment practices in supply chain prevents to achieve the anticipated outsourcing benefits. In this research, a three stage inventory model is developed to address the outsourcing issues with different shipment policies. Owing to inherent computational complexities of the problem with higher dimensions, various deterministic approaches practically fail. Proposed work, therefore, utilizes a nature inspired evolutionary algorithm, namely particle swarm optimization (PSO), to solve the problem. This paper applies enhanced particle swarm optimization (EPSO), a variant of particle swarm optimization for solution purpose. The results obtained delineate efficacy to handle the fluctuations in the possible shipment options and simultaneously deciding the optimal shipment policies.
Author Keywords: Inventory issue; Multilevel inventory model; Outsourcing; Particle swarm optimization
Index Keywords: Deterministic approach; Enhanced particle swarm optimization; Global economies; High quality; Higher dimensions; Inventory issue; Inventory models; Low costs; Outsource; Particle swarm; Swarm Intelligence; Three stages; Artificial intelligence; Cellular automata; Inventory control; Outsourcing; Supply chain management; Supply chains; Particle swarm optimization (PSO)

Authors: Haghpanah Y., DesJardins M.
Title: Using a trust model in decision making for supply chain management
Abstract: One of the critical factors for a successful cooperative relationship in a supply chain partnership is trust. Many real-world applications, such as Supply Chain Management (SCM), can be modeled using multi-agent systems. One shortcoming of current SCM models is that their trust models are ad hoc and do not have a strong theoretical basis. As a result, they are unable to model subtleties in agent behavior that can be used to build a more accurate trust model. We propose a trust model for SCM that is grounded in probabilistic game theory. In this model, trust can be gained through direct interactions and/or by asking for information from other trustworthy agents. We will use this model to simulate and study supply chain market behavior. Copyright © 2010, Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Decision theory; Game theory; Multi-agent systems; Supply chain management
Index Keywords: Agent behavior; Cooperative relationships; Critical factors; Direct interactions; Market behavior; Probabilistic games; Real-world application; Theoretical basis; Trust models; Decision making; Game theory; Intelligent agents; Multi agent systems; User interfaces; Supply chain management

Authors: Schellenberg S., Mohais A., Wagner N., Ibrahimov M., Michalewicz Z.
Title: Optimising supply chain networks by means of a hybridised simulation-based approach
Abstract: Supply chain management, in the scope of the described project, is about managing the flow of materials in a network of factories producing and transforming raw material into intermediate and final product, and the use of buffering instances such as storage tanks, silos and stockpiles. The system we present tries to reconcile the drivers of a supply chain: demand for final product and supply of raw material. In addition to balancing the material flow to honour physical constraints (i.e. storage capacities, minimum production rates, transportation bottlenecks, etc.), the system aims to maximise the overall output of the supply chain network. Other benefits from a business point of view are the reduction of time to generate a factory plan while providing better accuracy and visibility of the material flow. Reducing the costs for creating a plan allows for what-if-scenario analysis and strategic planning which would not have been possible otherwise. In order to optimise the material flow, an Evolutionary Algorithm (EA) was employed that incorporates operators handling business and general planning constraints. Furthermore, the EA utilises a discrete-event simulation (DES) with characteristics of continuous simulations as part of its fitness evaluation. We present preliminary results obtained from a project carried out in cooperation with an Australian ASX listed company manufacturing agricultural chemicals. © 2010 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Continuous simulation; Discrete events; Fitness evaluations; Flow of material; Listed companies; Material Flow; Physical constraints; Production rates; Simulation-based; Storage capacity; Storage tank; Supply chain network; Agricultural chemicals; Artificial intelligence; Commerce; Computer simulation; Evolutionary algorithms; Materials; Materials handling; Mathematical operators; Supply chain management

Authors: Ibrahimov M., Wagner N., Mohais A., Schellenberg S., Michalewicz Z.
Title: Comparison of cooperative and classical evolutionary algorithms for global supply chain optimisation
Abstract: This paper discusses global optimisation from a business perspective in the context of the supply chain operations. A two-silo supply chain was built for experimentation and two approaches were used for global optimisation: a classical evolutionary approach and a cooperative coevolutionary approach. The latter approach produced higher quality solutions due to its use of communication between silos. Additionally, a second problem was presented involving an existing Australian multi-factory sheet steel business. © 2010 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Business perspective; Co-evolutionary approach; Evolutionary approach; Global optimisation; Global supply chain; Optimisations; Sheet steel; Supply chain operation; Artificial intelligence; Evolutionary algorithms; Global optimization; Optimization; Steel sheet; Supply chain management; Supply chains

Authors: Holimchayachotikul P., Derrouiche R., Leksakul K., Guizzi G.
Title: B2B supply chain performance enhancement road map using data mining techniques
Abstract: Presently, modern B2B supply chain management (B2B-SCM) equipped with semi-automated data logging systems accumulate large volumes. However, each SC unit in B2B-SC still individually develops their performance. Besides, their linkages of performance attributes between SC units still lack vital information extraction to improve theirs. Therefore, this paper aims to propose an integrated framework between B2B supply chain (B2B-SC) performance evaluation systems and data mining techniques, developing relationship rules of collaborative performance attribute enhancement. The methodology is as follows. Firstly, B2B-SC performance evaluation questionnaires based on two levels able to characterize collaborative relation between two or more partners in their SC were gathered from the case study companies. The data set of relationships between enterprise and its direct customers of the case study companies in France was used for demonstration. Secondly, data cleaning and preparations for rule extraction were performed on the questionnaire database. The significance of attribute was calculated using attribute ranking algorithms by means of information gain based on ranker search. These results were used to choose the crucial attributes from each micro view. Thirdly, web graph analysis was performed on this data to confirm the strong attribute relationship. Next, association rule was deployed to extract performance attribute relationship rules grounded on support and confidence cross validation method. The quality of each recognized rule is tested and, from numerous rules, only those that are statistically very strong and contain vital information are selected. Last but not least, these rules are interpreted by domain experts and studied by domain engineers to build a collaborative performance attribute enhancement road map. Furthermore, the final rule set of extracted rules contains very interesting information relating to SCs and also point out the critical existing SC attribute improvement. Ultimately, companies in this SC are able to use this framework to design and adjust their units to conform with the exact customer needs.
Author Keywords: Association rule; Attribute ranking; Business to business (B2B); Data mining; Supply chain (SC)
Index Keywords: Attribute ranking; Business to business (B2B); Collaborative performance; Collaborative relations; Cross-validation methods; Customer need; Data cleaning; Data logging systems; Data mining techniques; Data sets; Domain experts; Information Extraction; Information gain; Integrated frameworks; Interesting information; Performance attributes; Performance evaluation; Performance evaluation system; Relationship rules; Road-maps; Rule extraction; Rule set; Semi-automated; Supply chain performance; Support and confidence; Web graph analysis; Association rules; Data mining; Information management; Maps; Roads and streets; Surveys; Systems science; User interfaces; Supply chain management

Authors: Chen Z., Wang H.
Title: Photovoltaic supply chain coordination under polysilicon capacity constraints
Abstract: This paper studies the photovoltaic supply chain coordination under polysilicon capacity constraints, and separately builds revenue sharing contract model under polysilicon capacity constraints and cooperative R&D contract model break polysilicon capacity constraints, the research shows that i) Under the revenue sharing contract for Photovoltaic supply chain under Polysilicon capacity constraints, the coordinated wholesale price decreases with the rate of revenue sharing increasing, and Polysilicon chips manufacturer (PCM)'s profit increases while the Photovoltaic system manufacturer (PSM)'s profit decreases with rate of revenue sharing increasing. ii) Under the cooperative R&D contract for Photovoltaic supply chain under Polysilicon capacity constraints, the coordinated wholesale price decreases with the rate of R&D fund provided by PSM increasing, and PCM's profit decreases while the PSM's profit increases with R&D fund provided by PSM increasing.
Author Keywords: Capacity constraints; Coordination; Photovoltaic supply chain; Polysilicon
Index Keywords: Capacity constraints; Coordination; Photovoltaic supply chain; Photovoltaic systems; Revenue sharing contracts; Revenue-sharing; Supply chain coordination; Whole sale prices; Information management; Information technology; Manufacture; Photovoltaic effects; Polysilicon; Profitability; Supply chain management; Supply chains; Data mining

Authors: Wang S., Yan J., Kaiquan X., Yuewen L., Long L., Huaiqing W.
Title: A conceptual modeling approach to quality management in the context of diary supply chain
Abstract: The Chinese milk scandal 2008 revealed a serious problem in supply chain quality management practices. In this research, conceptual modeling approach is used to represent entities and relationships in this field. The model is expected to provide an innovative perspective to supply chain quality management. With it, intelligent system can be designed to support quality information sharing between agents in the whole milk supply chain, and real time quality problem (e.g. causation of heavy metal residual) detection is feasible. © 2010 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Conceptual modeling; Milk; Social ontology; Static ontology; Supply chain quality management
Index Keywords: Conceptual modeling; Milk; Social ontology; Static ontology; Supply chain quality management; Data mining; Heavy metals; Information science; Intelligent agents; Intelligent systems; Ontology; Quality control; Quality management; Supply chains; Supply chain management

Authors: Yang Z., Huang H., Zhao Y., Chen Y.
Title: Development of integrated enterprise application integration platform facing steel circulation supply chain
Abstract: To solve the problem of enterprise application system integration confronting the steel circulation supply chain in the course of regional integration, this paper puts forward the development and application of the data exchange platform of the steel circulation supply chain based on EAI. The data exchange platform realizes the data exchange between one application system and other application systems through standardized interface layers. ©2010 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Data exchange platform; Enterprise application integration; Steel circulation; Supply chain management
Index Keywords: Application systems; Data exchange; Enterprise application integration; Enterprise application systems; Other applications; Regional integration; Standardized interfaces; Artificial intelligence; Curricula; Industry; Software engineering; Supply chains; Supply chain management

Authors: Wu Y., Wang X.
Title: A service-oriented computing model for supply chain collaboration
Abstract: The main issue facing technical collaboration in a supply chain is how to effectively integrate distributed computing resources that are dynamically different to achieve collaborative computing and to support new collaborative computing application demand. The paper proposes a service-oriented conceptual computing model to facilitate the collaboration of computing resource in the supply chain. In the model, each computing resource which participates in collaborative computing is encapsulated as a collaborative computing service, and is coupled into a loose collaboration computing alliance. An collaboration business event-driven mechanism also is designed to support dynamic and flexible collaborative computing among collaborative computing services of the model. ©2010 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Computing model; Service-oriented; Supply chain collaboration
Index Keywords: Collaborative computing; Computing model; Computing resource; Distributed computing resources; Event driven mechanisms; Service Oriented; Service-oriented computing model; Supply chain collaboration; Artificial intelligence; Software engineering; Supply chain management; Supply chains; Distributed computer systems

Authors: Mao Y., Zhong J., Yu X.
Title: An analysis of comprehensive benefits of information sharing in construction supply chain
Abstract: The benefits brought by information sharing in construction supply chain (ISCSC) can be manifested in many aspects. The calculation of added-value generated from information sharing is complicated and difficult, and this paper proposes to measure the above-mentioned benefits from three aspects: construction period, cost and quality. By establishing mathematical equations of added-value in terms of construction period, cost, quality and the cost of information sharing, we set up a model of comprehensive benefits of ISCSC after eliminating the influence of dimension. We also conduct simple application on the model by analyzing the actual case. ©2010 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Benefit analysis; Construction supply chain; Information sharing; Model of comprehensive benefits
Index Keywords: Benefit analysis; Comprehensive benefit; Construction period; Construction supply chain; Information sharing; Mathematical equations; Artificial intelligence; Information dissemination; Information management; Software engineering; Supply chain management; Supply chains; Information retrieval

Authors: Hu S., Xiao L.
Title: Research on partnership evaluation and selection in supply chain management
Abstract: The paper mainly discusses the coorperative relationship between enterprises in supply chain management. Through the analysis of the method of supply chain partnership evaluation and selection, the paper constructs the index system of partnership evaluation and selection and uses the grey evaluation method to give a comprehensive analysis on partnership evaluation and selection. ©2010 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Evaluation; Selection; Supply chain management
Index Keywords: Comprehensive analysis; Evaluation; Grey evaluation; Index systems; Selection; Artificial intelligence; Mergers and acquisitions; Software engineering; Supply chains; Supply chain management

Authors: Tong Y., Cheng X., Xiong X.
Title: An experimental study on the decision-making of internal supply chains in group corporations
Abstract: With the fast development of group companies in China, more and more supply chains are integrated in group corporations. This kind of internal supply chain which is composed by related companies is different from the traditional one. Through 4 scenes experimental study whose participants are MBA students, we find that a subsidiary manager who is suggested to share interest with other related companies in the same group will not accept abnormal related party transactions, such as purchase and sales, which is similar with what will happen in the traditional supply chain. Because internal supply chain members are related parties, they have more choices to allocate interests. Principal loan is favorable when there is only one plan provided to managers who will be the lenders, but they prefer to provide guarantee on loans borrowed by related companies when there are several optional plans. ©2010 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Decision making; Experimental study; Group corporations; Internal supply chain
Index Keywords: Experimental studies; Group corporations; Internal supply chain; Artificial intelligence; Decision making; Industry; Managers; Software engineering; Supply chain management; Teaching; Supply chains

Authors: Zheng D., Cao Y.
Title: Research on supply chain management system modeling based on multi-agent
Abstract: According to supply chain system with complex adaptive feature, a supply chain management system simulation model based on multi-agent is constructed. The collaborative relationships between the entities and the workflow of each agent in entity are analyzed; multi-agent dynamic federal organizational structure is proposed based on the federal structure of organizational structure in multi-agent , it is the basis to improve the efficiency of collaboration among agents. ©2010 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Multi-agent; Organizational structure; Supply chain
Index Keywords: Adaptive features; Collaborative relationships; Multi-Agent; Organizational structures; Supply chain management system; Supply chain systems; Artificial intelligence; Chains; Computer simulation; Management; Software engineering; Supply chains; Supply chain management

Authors: Jiang F., Zhao J., Ge H.
Title: Research on the application of improved association rule algorithm in Supply Chain Management
Abstract: Effective Supply Chain Management (SCM) approach must focus on flexible supply and production processes as well as rapidly respond to change of customer demands. To make up of existing drawbacks of association rule data mining algorithm, the paper brought out an improved algorithm and applies it in the product relativity analysis of SCM. Based on the algorithm, the solution of how the parts be arranged can achieve more cost-effective and higher profits can be achieved by data mining. The mining result can not only guide customers to correctly shopping, but also help manufacturers to design and produce goods, so that the companies can be in a better competitive position. © (2010) Trans Tech Publications, Switzerland.
Author Keywords: Apriori algorithm; Association rule; Data mining; Supply chain management
Index Keywords: Apriori algorithms; Association rule algorithm; Competitive position; Customer demands; Data mining algorithm; Improved algorithm; Production process; Relativity-analysis; Algorithms; Association rules; Data mining; Nanotechnology; Profitability; Supply chains; Supply chain management

Authors: Garg V.K., Viswanadham N.
Title: EcoSupply: A machine learning framework for analyzing the impact of ecosystem on global supply chain dynamics
Abstract: A global supply chain spans several regions and countries across the globe. A tremendous spurt in the extent of globalization has necessitated the need for modeling global supply chains in place of the conventional supply chains. In this paper, we propose a framework, EcoSupply, to analyze the supply chain ecosystem in a probabilistic setting unlike the existing methodologies, which presume a deterministic context. EcoSupply keeps track of the previous observations in order to facilitate improved prediction about the influence of uncertainties in the ecosystem, and provides a coherent mathematical exposition to construe the new associations, among the different supply chain stakeholders, in place of the existing links. To the best of our knowledge, EcoSupply is the first machine learning based paradigm to incorporate the dynamics of global supply chains. © 2010 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Global Sourcing; Machine Learning; Supply Chains
Index Keywords: Global sourcing; Global supply chain; Machine-learning; Global sourcing; Global supply chain; Chains; Ecosystems; Learning systems; Supply chain management; Artificial intelligence; Chains; Ecology; Ecosystems; Learning systems; Supply chains; Supply chains

Authors: Feng Y.
Title: A blackboard-based negotiation for collaboration in construction supply chain system
Abstract: The construction industry is being asked by more progressive clients to change its crude ways of working and to adopt more efficient business processes to improve its performance by adopting supply chain management (SCM) practices that have evolved in more advanced industries. Collaboration among the members of SCM plays a critical role to implement an effective SCM, but its implementation would not be easy only with the conventional information sharing mechanism. This study employs the idea of open tender concept with blackboard-based negotiation to develop a collaborative construction supply chain system. The open tender concept is designed to provide an open and free opportunity to all participants, which make a sound competition to obtain the tender. Blackboard-based negotiation is derived from the mechanism of negotiation among intelligent agents using a blackboard as a media where each agent exchange information. © 2010 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Blackboard; Collaborative construction supply chain System; Construction; Intelligent agents; Negotiation techniques
Index Keywords: Blackboard; Business Process; Collaborative construction; Construction supply chain; Information sharing mechanism; Negotiation techniques; Artificial intelligence; Chains; Construction industry; Information dissemination; Intelligent agents; Inventory control; Management science; Supply chains; Supply chain management

Authors: Ghandforoush P., Sen T.K.
Title: A DSS to manage platelet production supply chain for regional blood centers
Abstract: This paper presents a prototype decision support system for platelet production and blood mobile scheduling for a regional blood center. Unlike whole blood cells, platelets have a very short shelf life, which requires matching demand and supply closely. This is achieved by an efficient supply chain DSS that is optimized for delivery of platelets from production centers to transfusion centers, typically hospitals. One of the critical elements of the DSS is an embedded non-convex integer optimization model that assists the regional blood center manager to schedule the shuttle transportation of whole blood from collection sites to the regional processing center. The proposed non-convex integer model is transformed to a linear 0-1 problem using a two-step conversion process. The transformed model is successfully solved and the optimal solution is reached for the test data. An application of the integrated DSS using data from a regional blood center is described. The results suggest that the proposed DSS better meets the daily demand by producing a superior production plan and mobile assignment schedule. © 2010 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Blood bank DSS; DSS; Integer nonlinear programming; Platelet supply management
Index Keywords: Blood bank; Conversion process; Critical elements; Demand and supply; DSS; Integer optimization; Integer-nonlinear programming; Optimal solutions; Production plans; Regional processing centers; Shelf life; Test data; Whole blood; Artificial intelligence; Decision support systems; Decision theory; Integer programming; Nonlinear programming; Optimization; Platelets; Production control; Supply chain management; Supply chains; Blood

Authors: Thomassey S.
Title: Sales forecasts in clothing industry: The key success factor of the supply chain management
Abstract: Like many others, Textileapparel companies have to deal with a very competitive environment and have to manage consumers which become more demanding. Thus, to stay competitive, companies rely on sophisticated information systems and logistic skills, and especially accurate and reliable forecasting systems. However, forecasters have to deal with some singular constraints of the textileapparel market such as for instance the volatile demand, the strong seasonality of sales, the wide number of items with short life cycle or the lack of historical data. To respond to these constraints, companies have implemented specific forecasting systems often simple but robust. After the study of existing practices in the clothing industry, we propose different forecasting models which perform more accurate and more reliable sales forecasts. These models rely on advanced methods such as fuzzy logic, neural networks and data mining. In order to evaluate the benefits of these methods for the supply chain and more especially for the reduction of the bullwhip effect, a simulation based on real data of sourcing and forecasting processes is performed and analyzed. © 2010 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Clothing industry; Sales forecasts; Sourcing simulation; Textileapparel supply chain
Index Keywords: Bullwhip effects; Clothing industry; Competitive environment; Forecasting models; Forecasting system; Historical data; Key success factors; Seasonality; Simulation-based; Sourcing simulation; Textile-apparel; Forecasting; Fuzzy logic; Fuzzy neural networks; Industry; Sales; Supply chains; Supply chain management

Authors: Warren Liao T., Chang P.C.
Title: Impacts of forecast, inventory policy, and lead time on supply chain inventoryA numerical study
Abstract: This paper first proposes the use of metaheuristic, to combine with exponential smoothing methods, in forecasting future demands and in determining the optimal inventory policy values for each node in a supply chain network based on historical demand or order streams without the need of any prior knowledge about the demand distribution or distribution fitting. The effects of five demand forecasting methods, two inventory policies, and three lead times on the total inventory cost of a 3-echelon serial supply chain system are then investigated. The effect of sharing the demand information for planning the inventories is also compared with that of no sharing. For testing, 15 quarterly and 15 monthly time series were taken from the M3 Competition and are considered as the multi-item demand streams to be fulfilled in the supply chain. The results indicate that: (1) the damped Pegel forecasting method is the best in terms of prediction errors because it outperforms others in three of five measures, followed by the simple exponential smoothing that wins one of the remaining two and ties the damped Pegel in one; (2) the supply chain inventory cost increases with increasing lead time and echelon level of the supply chain when the (s, S) policy is used, but not the (r, Q) policy; (3) the (r, Q) inventory policy generally incurs lower supply chain inventory cost than the (s, S) policy; (4) sharing demand information reduces inventory cost and the reduction is higher for (s, S) than for (r, Q); (5) the best demand forecasting method for minimizing inventory cost varies with the inventory policy used and lead time; and (6) the correlation between forecasting errors and inventory costs is either negligible or minimal. © 2010 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Ant colony optimization; Demand forecasting; Information sharing; Inventory cost; Inventory policy; Lead time; Metaheuristic; Supply chain
Index Keywords: Ant-colony optimization; Demand forecasting; Information sharing; Inventory costs; Inventory policies; Lead time; Metaheuristic; Algorithms; Artificial intelligence; Chains; Competition; Costs; Errors; Forecasting; Heuristic methods; Information dissemination; Information management; Information retrieval; Inventory control; Optimization; Supply chain management; Time series; Time series analysis; Supply chains

Authors: Li Y., Kramer M.R., Beulens A.J.M., Van Der Vorst J.G.A.J.
Title: A framework for early warning and proactive control systems in food supply chain networks
Abstract: It is inherent to food supply chain networks that performance deviations occur occasionally due to variations in product quality and quantity. To reduce losses, one wants to be informed about such deviations as soon as possible, preferably even before they occur. Then it is possible to take actions to prevent or reduce negative consequences. In practice, extensive operational data is recorded, forming a valuable source for early warning and proactive control systems, i.e. decision support systems for prediction and prevention of such performance problems. Data mining methods are ideal for analyzing such data sources and extracting useable information from them. In this paper, we present a novel framework for early warning and proactive control systems that combine expert knowledge and data mining methods to exploit recorded data. We discuss the implementation of a prototype system and the experiences from a case study regarding the applicability of the framework. © 2010 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Data mining; Early warning; Knowledge management; Proactive control
Index Keywords: Data mining methods; Data source; Early warning; Expert knowledge; Operational data; Performance problems; Proactive control; Product quality; Prototype system; Agriculture; Artificial intelligence; Control theory; Decision support systems; Decision theory; Food supply; Knowledge management; Supply chain management; Supply chains; Data mining

Authors: Du L., Wang Z., Rao C.
Title: Automotive integrated supply chain management decision support system
Abstract: For any mature enterprise which has integrated modern management concept, it should have a set of perfect computer decision support system in order to provide a scientific decision basis for the decision maker to carry on management and planning. In this paper, on the basis of automotive integrated supply chain management decision model and the optimized algorithm, a set of automotive integrated supply chain management decision support system is developed independently by using the sofeware-Matlab7.0, which can provide a scientific and reasonable decision basis for managers verified by examples. ©2010 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Decision; Demand forecasting; Integrated supply chain management; Performance evaluation; Supplier evaluation and selection; Support system
Index Keywords: Decision; Demand forecasting; Integrated supply chain management; Performance evaluation; Supplier Evaluations; Support system; Artificial intelligence; Communication systems; Decision making; Decision support systems; Decision theory; Forecasting; Planning; Supply chains; Supply chain management

Authors: Di Giacomo L., Patrizi G.
Title: Methodological analysis of supply chains management applications
Abstract: Formal modelling may be used to express management operational plans to achieve the desired normative objectives of firms. The plans so formulated should be demonstrably optimal with regard to certain specific objectives assumed by top management and ought to provide accurate results, when enacted, with a given tolerance at a prespecified probability. Modelling Decision Support Systems is based on various alternative methodologies: managerial-situational, interpretative or formal-deductive, which affect the results and precision obtainable. The third approach requires dynamical nonlinear stochastic modelling to determine precise Supply Chain Management (SCM) plans, without incurring in the limitations that may characterize the former approaches. The aim of this paper is to examine different management methodologies, to determine the most appropriate implementation for accurate SCM plans. Two well known SCM implementations, the bullwhip effect and the collaborative planning and extensions will be examined under different methodologies for clarity and to verify their limitations. © 2010 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Decision support systems; Modelling systems and languages; Set-valued mappings; Supply chain management; System dynamics
Index Keywords: Bullwhip effects; Collaborative planning; Decision supports; Formal modelling; Management applications; Operational plan; Set-valued mapping; Stochastic modelling; Supply chain management system; Top management; Artificial intelligence; Decision making; Decision support systems; Decision theory; Linguistics; Supply chains; System theory; Supply chain management

Authors: Pino R., Fernández I., de la Fuente D., Parreño J., Priore P.
Title: Supply chain modelling using a multi-agent system
Abstract: PurposeThe purpose of this paper is to focus on a supply chain (SC) simulation of all its management processes by means of a multi-agent system (MAS). Design/methodology/approachNowadays, the company must develop its activity in an environment characterized by: globalization, hard competitiveness, the necessity of flexibility and of answering dynamically to a changing demand. Thus, a distributed, autonomous approach, strong enough to face changes is necessary, which is what MASs contribute to. An agent can represent each of the components that form the SC. Then the resulting agent system will own similar characteristics to the ones in the studied SC: autonomy, social abilities, reactivity, pro-activity. FindingsWhen analysing the demand for each SC member (from manufacturer to final consumer), one can observe that while consumer demand is a relatively stable feature, the upper link in the chain (the manufacturer), presents a very pronounced variability. This is known as the "bullwhip effect" or "forrester effect" and is mainly due to the fact that the SC members' strategies are not considered as a whole but as a sum of individual strategies. In the proposed system, each agent will be communicated with other "agents" who will be the only responsible for making forecasts based on information provided to it by all components of the chain. The ultimate goal is for each SC echelon to satisfy its own objectives, while at the same time meet the local and external constraints. Research limitations/implicationsIn this work a standard SC is proposed (one manufacturer – one distributor – one wholesaler – one retailer) although it could easily be modified to incorporate a bigger number of members in each echelon within the SC. Originality/valueThe paper shows the benefits of using artificial intelligence in the SC management. © 2010, Emerald Group Publishing Limited.
Author Keywords: Control systems; Intelligent agents; Process management; Supply chain management

Authors: Andreea D., Adrian C.L., Alexandru S., Daniel D.S.
Title: Multi-agents and GIS framework for collaborative supply chain management applications: Case study: Internet trade business network
Abstract: In this paper we present an agent-based framework for modeling supply chain management business flows. A supplier search algorithm that takes geographic data into consideration is introduced as well as an ontology that extends the Network Description Language (NDL) with additional information related to the internet provider's network geographic area and costs. We also present a circuit discovery method (flow) similar to the Dijkstra algorithm but using a different distance metric. The cost function takes into account a series of parameters such as: committed information rate, current segment link load, current segment total transfer capacity, latency measured, reliability of a link, additional costs.
Author Keywords: Geographic information system (GIS); Intelligent agents; Ontologies; Semantic web services (SWS)
